author: Jeff Parsons
title: Amazon denies employees are 'crying at their desks in punishing office culture' after explosive newspaper article
text:
Amazon has come a long way from just selling books online .
The company builds its own gadgets , experiments with drones and puts a lot of effort into managing its tax payments .
But what it doesn’t do is push workers so hard they cry at their desks.
The online giant issued a reply this week to an explosive New York Times article that made that accusation (along with plenty of others) regarding its "bruising" workplace practices.
"When the story came out, we knew it misrepresented Amazon,” wrote Jay Carney, Amazon’s senior vice president for global corporate affairs, in an open blog post .
Getty Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, has vigorously defended his company
"We presented the Times with our findings several weeks ago, hoping they might take action to correct the record. They haven’t, which is why we decided to write about it ourselves.”
Carney goes on to state that the Times got most of their facts wrong and the main source had an axe to grind after Amazon caught him defrauding vendors and falsifying business records.
“Had the reporters checked their facts, the story they published would have been a lot less sensational, a lot more balanced, and, let’s be honest, a lot more boring,” he wrote.
"It might not have merited the front page, but it would have been closer to the truth."
But, rather than let the matter lie, the Times hit back with an open letter on the same day .
Getty An employee in the Amazon warehouse
The newspaper stood by its story and the “more than a hundred current and former employees, at various levels and divisions, over many months.”
Carney himself decided to respond , yet again, and keep the debate ticking over.
At which point, it's fair to say, most of us stopped caring.
But it does show that the Times hit a nerve with its piece and maybe Amazon isn't as immune to criticism as many thought.
